text: Any time I hear someone explain why they use R, not Julia or whatever it comes down to libraries.

elements.text: Any time I hear someone explain why they use R, not Julia or whatever it comes down to libraries.

text:
I remember not so long ago everyone said:
> Python will never displace Perl. You can’t compete with the number of libraries on CPAN

elements.text: I remember not so long ago everyone said:
Python will never displace Perl. You can’t compete with the number of libraries on CPAN

text: I don’t even think many R users feel that Julia will *never* replace R. They just might not agree about whether it’s at a place yet where they’d want to switch, which is fair.

elements.text: I don’t even think many R users feel that Julia will
replace R. They just might not agree about whether it’s at a place yet where they’d want to switch, which is fair.

text: Yea most R people don't care about a lot of things, I used to be one. What they care about is sound, vetted, correct, statistical methods being easy to use. Julia has a long way to go. Sure it will happen, but a stable ANOVA package would be a good start :stuck_out_tongue:

elements.text: Yea most R people don't care about a lot of things, I used to be one. What they care about is sound, vetted, correct, statistical methods being easy to use. Julia has a long way to go. Sure it will happen, but a stable ANOVA package would be a good start

text: Rstudio is kinda nice. It's kind of like matlab lite that's equally functional. Supposedly you can write python in it now?
